canonical_explanation.text: A circle is the set of all points equidistant from a fixed point (centre). Key theorems: equal chords subtend equal angles at the centre; the perpendicular from the centre to a chord bisects the chord; equal chords are equidistant from the centre. The angle subtended by an arc at the centre is twice the angle at any point on the remaining circle. Angles in the same segment are equal. The angle in a semicircle is 90°. Opposite angles of a cyclic quadrilateral sum to 180°.
rules: Equal chords subtend equal angles at the centre
Perpendicular from centre to chord bisects the chord
Equal chords are equidistant from the centre
Angles in the same segment are equal
Opposite angles of a cyclic quadrilateral are supplementary

questions.question_text: The perpendicular from the centre of a circle to a chord:
questions.explanation_correct: The perpendicular drawn from the centre of a circle to a chord bisects the chord (divides it into two equal parts).
questions.explanation_incorrect: This is a fundamental theorem: the perpendicular from the centre bisects the chord.

questions.question_text: Equal chords of a circle subtend ___ angles at the centre.
questions.explanation_correct: Equal chords subtend equal angles at the centre. This follows from the SSS congruence of the triangles formed.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Equal chords → equal central angles. The converse is also true.

questions.question_text: Equal chords of a circle are equidistant from the centre.
questions.explanation_correct: Equal chords are at equal perpendicular distances from the centre. The converse is also true.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Equal chords → equidistant from centre. This is proved using the perpendicular bisector property.

questions.question_text: The angle subtended by an arc at the centre is ___ the angle subtended at any point on the remaining circle.
questions.explanation_correct: The inscribed angle theorem states that the central angle is twice the inscribed angle subtended by the same arc.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Central angle = 2 × inscribed angle for the same arc.

questions.question_text: The angle in a semicircle is:
questions.explanation_correct: A diameter subtends a 180° angle at the centre. The inscribed angle = 180°/2 = 90°. So the angle in a semicircle is always 90°.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The inscribed angle on a semicircle is always 90° (half the central angle of 180°).

questions.question_text: Angles in the same segment of a circle are ___.
questions.explanation_correct: All angles subtended by the same arc at points on the same side are equal. This is the 'angles in the same segment' theorem.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Angles in the same segment are equal — they all subtend the same arc.

questions.question_text: The opposite angles of a cyclic quadrilateral are:
questions.explanation_correct: Opposite angles of a cyclic quadrilateral (inscribed in a circle) are supplementary — they add up to 180°.
questions.explanation_incorrect: In a cyclic quadrilateral, opposite angles sum to 180° (supplementary).

questions.question_text: A chord of length 10 cm is at a distance of 5 cm from the centre. The radius of the circle is:
questions.explanation_correct: Half chord = 5 cm, distance from centre = 5 cm. By Pythagoras: r² = 5² + 5² = 50. r = √50 = 5√2 cm.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Using Pythagoras with half-chord (5) and distance (5): r = √(25+25) = 5√2 cm.

questions.question_text: If ABCD is a cyclic quadrilateral and angle A = 80°, then angle C = 100°.
questions.explanation_correct: Opposite angles of a cyclic quadrilateral are supplementary. Angle C = 180° − 80° = 100°.
questions.explanation_incorrect: In a cyclic quadrilateral: angle A + angle C = 180°, so angle C = 100°.

questions.question_text: If the central angle for an arc is 120°, the inscribed angle subtended by the same arc is:
questions.explanation_correct: Inscribed angle = (1/2) × central angle = (1/2)(120°) = 60°.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Inscribed angle is half the central angle: 120°/2 = 60°.

questions.question_text: Two chords AB and CD of a circle are equal. If the distance of AB from centre is 4 cm, the distance of CD from centre is:
questions.explanation_correct: Equal chords are equidistant from the centre. Since AB = CD and AB is 4 cm from centre, CD is also 4 cm from centre.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Equal chords → equal distance from centre = 4 cm.

questions.question_text: A chord of a circle of radius 13 cm is at distance 5 cm from the centre. The length of the chord is:
questions.explanation_correct: Half chord = √(13² − 5²) = √(169 − 25) = √144 = 12 cm. Full chord = 24 cm.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Half-chord² + distance² = radius². Half-chord = √(169−25) = 12. Chord = 24 cm.

questions.question_text: O is the centre of a circle. Angle BOC = 100° where B and C are on the circle. Angle BAC (A on the major arc) is:
questions.explanation_correct: A is on the major arc. The inscribed angle BAC = (1/2) × central angle BOC = 50°.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Inscribed angle = half of central angle on the same arc = 100°/2 = 50°.

questions.question_text: AB is a diameter of a circle. C is any point on the circle. Angle ACB =
questions.explanation_correct: AB is a diameter, so the arc AB is a semicircle. The angle in a semicircle is always 90°.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Angle in a semicircle = 90°. Any angle inscribed in a semicircle is a right angle.

questions.question_text: ABCD is a cyclic quadrilateral. Angle A = 70°, angle B = 110°. Find angle D:
questions.explanation_correct: Opposite angles are supplementary. Angle B + angle D = 180°. Angle D = 180° − 110° = 70°.

questions.question_text: In a circle of radius 10 cm, a chord is 12 cm long. Its distance from the centre is ___ cm.
questions.explanation_correct: Half chord = 6. Distance = √(10² − 6²) = √(100 − 36) = √64 = 8 cm.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Distance = √(r² − (chord/2)²) = √(100 − 36) = 8 cm.

questions.question_text: Two points A and B on a circle subtend angle APB = 40° at point P on the major arc. The angle at the centre AOB is:
questions.explanation_correct: Central angle = 2 × inscribed angle = 2 × 40° = 80°.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Central angle is twice the inscribed angle on the same arc: 2 × 40° = 80°.

questions.question_text: If a parallelogram is inscribed in a circle, it must be a rectangle.
questions.explanation_correct: In a cyclic parallelogram, opposite angles are both equal (parallelogram) and supplementary (cyclic). So each angle = 90°, making it a rectangle.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Opposite angles: equal (parallelogram) and supplementary (cyclic) → each = 90° → rectangle.

questions.question_text: O is the centre. OM ⊥ chord AB and ON ⊥ chord CD. If AB = CD, then:
questions.explanation_correct: Equal chords are equidistant from the centre. Since AB = CD, OM = ON.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Equal chords → equal perpendicular distances from centre. OM = ON.

questions.question_text: Angles subtended by the same chord on the same side of the chord are:
questions.explanation_correct: Angles in the same segment (same side of a chord) are equal. They subtend the same arc.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Same arc → same inscribed angle. All angles in the same segment are equal.

questions.question_text: Two chords AB and CD intersect at P inside the circle. If AB = 12 cm and CD = 16 cm, which chord is closer to the centre?
questions.explanation_correct: The longer chord is closer to the centre. Since CD (16 cm) > AB (12 cm), CD is closer to the centre.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Longer chord → smaller distance from centre. CD is longer, so it's closer.

questions.question_text: O is the centre of a circle. Angle AOB = 90°. Points C and D are on the major and minor arcs respectively. Then angle ACB + angle ADB =
questions.explanation_correct: C is on major arc: angle ACB = (1/2)(90°) = 45°. D is on minor arc: angle ADB = (1/2)(reflex angle AOB) = (1/2)(270°) = 135°. Sum = 45° + 135° = 180°.
questions.explanation_incorrect: C on major arc: angle ACB = 45°. D on minor arc: angle ADB = 135°. Sum = 180°.

questions.question_text: ABCD is a cyclic quadrilateral. If angle A = 3x and angle C = 2x + 30, find x:
questions.explanation_correct: Opposite angles: A + C = 180°. 3x + 2x + 30 = 180. 5x = 150. x = 30.

questions.question_text: The longest chord of a circle passes through the centre and is called the ___.
questions.explanation_correct: The diameter is the longest chord of a circle. It passes through the centre.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A chord through the centre is the diameter — the longest possible chord.

questions.question_text: If angle subtended by an arc at the centre is 150°, the angle subtended at a point on the remaining arc is:
questions.explanation_correct: Inscribed angle = (1/2) × central angle = 150°/2 = 75°.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Inscribed angle is half the central angle: 150/2 = 75°.

questions.question_text: If the sum of opposite angles of a quadrilateral is 180°, the quadrilateral is cyclic.
questions.explanation_correct: This is the converse of the cyclic quadrilateral theorem. If opposite angles are supplementary, the quadrilateral can be inscribed in a circle.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The converse: supplementary opposite angles → cyclic quadrilateral.

questions.question_text: How many circles can pass through three non-collinear points?
questions.explanation_correct: Through any three non-collinear points, exactly one circle can be drawn. This is a unique circle.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Three non-collinear points determine a unique circle (the circumscribed circle).

questions.question_text: If two chords of a circle are equal, the arcs they cut off are:
questions.explanation_correct: Equal chords cut off equal arcs. If AB = CD, then arc AB = arc CD (the minor arcs are equal and the major arcs are equal).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Equal chords subtend equal arcs in a circle.

questions.question_text: AB is a chord of a circle with centre O. M is the midpoint of AB. Then OM is:
questions.explanation_correct: The line from the centre to the midpoint of a chord is perpendicular to the chord. This is the converse of the perpendicular bisector theorem.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Centre to midpoint of chord → perpendicular to the chord.

questions.question_text: ABCD is a cyclic quadrilateral with angle B = 85°. Find angle D:
questions.explanation_correct: Opposite angles B and D are supplementary: B + D = 180°. D = 180° − 85° = 95°.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Cyclic quadrilateral: B + D = 180° → D = 95°.

questions.question_text: In a circle of radius 5 cm, two parallel chords of lengths 6 cm and 8 cm are on the same side of the centre. The distance between them is:
questions.explanation_correct: Distance of 6 cm chord from centre = √(25−9) = 4 cm. Distance of 8 cm chord from centre = √(25−16) = 3 cm. Same side: distance between = 4 − 3 = 1 cm.

questions.question_text: A, B, C are three points on a circle. Angle BAC = 35°. The angle BOC (O is centre) is:
questions.explanation_correct: Central angle = 2 × inscribed angle = 2 × 35° = 70°.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Central angle BOC = 2 × inscribed angle BAC = 2(35°) = 70°.

questions.question_text: In cyclic quadrilateral PQRS, angle P = 110°. Angle R = ___°.
questions.explanation_correct: P + R = 180° (opposite angles). R = 180° − 110° = 70°.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Opposite angles: P + R = 180° → R = 70°.

questions.question_text: The perpendicular bisector of a chord passes through the centre of the circle.
questions.explanation_correct: The perpendicular bisector of any chord passes through the centre. This is because the centre is equidistant from both endpoints of the chord.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The perpendicular bisector of a chord always passes through the centre of the circle.

questions.question_text: In a circle, if angle ABC = 30° (inscribed angle) and AB is a chord, the arc AC (not containing B) subtends ___ at the centre:
questions.explanation_correct: The central angle is twice the inscribed angle: 2 × 30° = 60°.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Central angle = 2 × inscribed angle = 60°.

questions.question_text: ABCD is cyclic with angle BAD = 100° and angle BCD = ?
questions.explanation_correct: Opposite angles: BAD + BCD = 180°. BCD = 180° − 100° = 80°.

questions.question_text: The diameter of a circle is the ___ chord.
questions.explanation_correct: The diameter is the longest chord of a circle, passing through the centre.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A chord through the centre (diameter) is longer than any chord that does not pass through the centre.

questions.question_text: In a circle, AB is a diameter. If angle CAB = 35° where C is on the circle, find angle ABC:
questions.explanation_correct: Angle ACB = 90° (angle in semicircle). In triangle ABC: angle ABC = 180° − 90° − 35° = 55°.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Angle in semicircle = 90°. So angle ABC = 180° − 90° − 35° = 55°.

questions.question_text: Can a trapezium (with one pair of non-equal parallel sides) be cyclic?

options.text: Only if it is a rectangle

questions.explanation_correct: An isosceles trapezium (non-parallel sides equal) is cyclic because its opposite angles are supplementary.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Only isosceles trapeziums are cyclic. A general trapezium is not cyclic.

questions.question_text: Three chords AB, CD, EF of a circle have lengths 10 cm, 10 cm, 8 cm. Their distances from the centre are d₁, d₂, d₃ respectively. Then:
questions.explanation_correct: AB = CD = 10 cm → d₁ = d₂ (equal chords equidistant). EF = 8 cm < 10 cm → d₃ > d₁ (shorter chord is farther from centre). So d₁ = d₂ < d₃.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Equal chords: d₁ = d₂. Shorter chord EF is farther from centre: d₃ > d₁.

questions.question_text: If two arcs of a circle are equal, the chords corresponding to them are also equal.
questions.explanation_correct: Equal arcs subtend equal chords. This is the converse of the theorem that equal chords cut off equal arcs.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Equal arcs → equal central angles → equal chords.

questions.question_text: In a circle, chord AB = 16 cm and the radius is 10 cm. The distance from centre to chord is:
questions.explanation_correct: Half chord = 8 cm. Distance = √(10² − 8²) = √(100 − 64) = √36 = 6 cm.

questions.question_text: A and B are two points on a circle with centre O. Angle AOB = 60°. If C and D are points on the major and minor arcs respectively, then:
questions.explanation_correct: C on major arc: angle ACB = 60°/2 = 30°. D on minor arc: reflex angle AOB = 300°, angle ADB = 300°/2 = 150°.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Major arc → angle = 60°/2 = 30°. Minor arc → angle = (360°−60°)/2 = 150°.

questions.question_text: If ABCD is a cyclic quadrilateral with AB as a diameter, angle ADC =
questions.explanation_correct: AB is a diameter. Angle ACB = 90° (angle in semicircle). In cyclic quadrilateral, angle ADC = angle subtended by arc ABC at D. Since AB is a diameter, the arc from A to B through C (the semicircle containing C) subtends 90° at D. Actually: angle ADB = 90° if AB is diameter and D is on the circle. But here ABCD is a cyclic quadrilateral with AB as diameter, so both C and D are on the circle. Angle ACB = 90° and we need angle ADC. Without more info, angle ADC depends on where D is. However, if AB subtends angle ADB = 90° (as AB is diameter), then angle ADB = 90°. But the question asks angle ADC. Since D is between A and B on the arc (in the quadrilateral), this gets complex. Given the options, angle ADC = 90° is the intended answer (D is on the semicircle with diameter AB).
questions.explanation_incorrect: If AB is a diameter, any angle inscribed in the semicircle (angle on AB) is 90°.

questions.question_text: How many common points can a circle and a line have at most?
questions.explanation_correct: A line can intersect a circle in at most 2 points (secant), or touch it at 1 point (tangent), or not intersect at all.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A line can meet a circle at 0 (no intersection), 1 (tangent), or 2 (secant) points. Maximum is 2.

questions.question_text: If the inscribed angle is 40°, the central angle subtended by the same arc is ___°.
questions.explanation_correct: Central angle = 2 × inscribed angle = 2 × 40° = 80°.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Central angle = 2 × 40° = 80°.

questions.question_text: In a cyclic quadrilateral ABCD, angle A : angle C = 4:5. Find angle A:
If two chords of a circle are equidistant from the centre, they are equal in length.
questions.explanation_correct: This is the converse: equidistant from centre → equal chords. It follows from the Pythagoras theorem applied to the right triangles formed.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Equidistant chords from the centre must be equal. This is the converse of 'equal chords are equidistant.'

questions.question_text: In a circle with centre O, angles in alternate segments are:

options.text: Angles in alternate segments theorem relates to tangent, not covered in Class 9

questions.explanation_correct: The alternate segment theorem involves tangents to a circle, which is covered in Class 10, not Class 9. In Class 9, we study inscribed angles, not tangent-related theorems.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The alternate segment theorem involves tangents, which is a Class 10 topic.

questions.question_text: ABCD is a cyclic quadrilateral with angle A = (2x + 4)° and angle C = (3x − 14)°. Find angle B if angle D = (2x + 10)°:
questions.explanation_incorrect: First find x from A + C = 180°: x = 38. Then D = 86°, so B = 180° − 86° = 94°.
